results.title: Swimming upstream
results.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Andrew Mason, Paul Pompian, Karen Baldwin, Howard Baldwin, LLC and Crusader Entertainment
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Anthony and Diane Fingleton, “Swimming upstream” chronicles the turbulent life of the Fingleton family in 1950s Brisbane. In particular, that of Anthony (Tony) Fingleton (Jesse Spencer), younger brother John (Tim Draxl), and their father Harold (Geoffrey Rush). Tony and John were swimming champions, Tony in backstroke and John in freestyle. The siblings were close, especially during the years in which Tony, bullied by older brother Harold Jnr (mimicking the boorish behaviour of his father) for being effeminate finds solace in John and their mother. The patriarch is an overbearing presence, his emotions vacillating between devotion and belligerence. His mood, affected by alcoholism, takes a violent turn directed towards the rest of the family. Harold takes it upon himself to coach his two sons to swimming success but creates a cleft between them when he forces John to change strokes and race against his brother. Regret, machismo and emotional repression play out in this poignant film of a dysfunctional family that makes effective use of split screens to intensify the numerous races and an evocative instrumental soundtrack. Cast also includes Judy Davis as Harold’s long suffering wife Dora.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Russell Mulcahy, Andrew Mason, Paul Pompian, Karen Baldwin, Howard Baldwin, LLC and Crusader Entertainment

results.title: Swimming pool
results.creator_credit: Francois Ozon, Marc Missonnier, Olivier Delbosc, Foz, Gimages Films, France2 Cinema and Fidelite Productions
results.brief_description: In his first film in English, writer/director Francois Ozon directs two actors that have worked with him before - Charlotte Rampling (“Under The Sand”) and Ludivine Sagnier (“8 Women”). Enlisting performances that essentially carry the narrative, Ozon’s preference for films dealing with psychological manipulation is evident with this film. Sarah Morton (Rampling) is an English crime writer who jaded by her monetary success and fame seeks out her publisher John Bosload (Charles Dance) and a morning whiskey to help cheer her up. He suggests she uses his holiday house in France for a break and possibly some inspiration for her next novel in a detective series she has been writing. Her time in France seems to be just what she needs, until a visit by Bosload’s estranged daughter Julie (Sagnier) throws her staid and orderly self into disarray. Sexually provocative and physically beautiful, Julie becomes her new fascination and the two women form a bond when murder and muse become intertwined in their summer idyll by the swimming pool. Charlotte Rampling was winner of Best Actress from the European Film Academy in 2003 for her role of Morton. Official selection Cannes 2003. Cast includes Marc Fayolle and Jean-Marie Lamour.

results.title: Swimming in the primary school
results.creator_credit: Derek Monk and Educational Foundation for Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
This film studies swimming lessons with junior children showing three levels: a class of beginners; a mixed-ability class; and a class in which all the children can swim and are working to make their strokes more efficient and to build up stamina.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Swimming in the backyard
results.creator_credit: Polly Watkins, Beth Frey and Blackout Productions
results.brief_description: This short documentary was commissioned by SBS Independent as part of its ‘Australia by Numbers’ series about community life in various postcodes around Australia. This episode centres on the municipal pool in Prahran, an inner suburb of Melbourne. Every summer, since it was built in the 1960’s, the pool has been a magnet for a diverse range of locals who go there both to socialise and exercise. A constant over the years has been the pool’s two long serving managers, who know and are known by almost everyone.

results.title: Swimming and diving
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Big Fights Olympic Library, UP Sports and Golden Years
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
A history of the modern Olympic Games which utilises archival media footage to illustrate some of the heroic achievements of Olympic swimmers and divers. This tape includes footage; the springboard diving win of Pat McCormick in 1956; the Gold Medal wins of Shane Gould, Dawn Fraser and Murray Rose.

results.title: Swimming
results.brief_description: A young girl is given a video recorder as a gift. Structured as a video and super-8 diary, this compelling short film investigates the devastating effects on a child of adult secrets. This exceptional Australian short film is a first person narrative conveyed completely through point of view and mise-en-scene. Cast features Steve Jacobs and Lynette Curran.
